instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PPVOUT_SW_LCDBKLT: What is PPVOUT_SW_LCDBKLT? PPVOUT_SW_LCDBKLT is the voltage rail for the backlight of the LCD screen. .
definitions.LVDS_DDC_CLK: What is LVDS_DDC_CLK? LVDS_DDC_CLK Is the DDC clock line between the graphics processor and the screen. DDC is a protocol for identifying a screen so that you know what resolution/refresh rate it wants. This is necessary for screen detection, inductor on this data line must be good and DDC voltage must be going to the LCD screen for it to work. .
definitions.LVDS_DDC_DATA: What is LVDS_DDC_DATA? LVDS_DDC_DATA Is the DDC data line between the graphics processor and the screen. DDC is a protocol for identifying a screen so that you know what resolution/refresh rate it wants. This is necessary for screen detection, inductor on this data line must be good and DDC voltage must be going to the LCD screen for it to work. .
definitions.PPBUS_SW_LCDBKLT_PWR: What is PPBUS_SW_LCDBKLT_PWR? PPBUS_SW_LCDBKLT_PWR is PPBUS_G3H after it has passed through a backlight fuse and a transistor that allows power through when BKLT_PLT_RST_L and LCD_BKLT_EN are present. .
definitions.LCDBKLT_EN_DIV: What is LCDBKLT_EN_DIV? LCDBKLT_EN_DIV must be low in order for the P channel MOSFET to have a lower voltage on the gate than is present on the source to allow backlight voltage to flow through the backlight circuit. .
definitions.Q9706: What is Q9706? Q9706 takes PPBUS_G3H's vltage and sends it through to the backlight circuit. If Q9706 is not allowing PPBUS_G3H through, you will get no voltage on the backlight circuit. Q9706 is a P channel MOSFET, meaning power will flow through it when the voltage on the gate is lower than on the source. Look at pin 3. R9788 takes the 12.6v that is on the source and places it right on pin 3. This will set Q9706 to "off", and not allow it to pass power, as the voltage on the source and the gate are identical..

The next voltages should be present without lcd plug to the machine? or they need the lcd to be plug to test ?:[/FONT][/FONT][/SIZE]

and what I did so far and that didn't fix the machine was replace <CHIP>U5400</CHIP> also paths to [/FONT][/FONT][/SIZE][FONT=Courier New][SIZE=3]<RESISTOR>R5400</RESISTOR>[/SIZE][/FONT][SIZE=14px][FONT=Courier][FONT=Courier]  now have wires because corrosion destroy the old paths , I replace also <TRANSISTOR>Q5300</TRANSISTOR> and trace wires to <RESISTOR>R5301</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R5303</RESISTOR> from <TRANSISTOR>Q5300</TRANSISTOR> because bad paths, <RESISTOR>R5301</RESISTOR> was replace too.

I ultrasonic the board

And I almost forget , pins on the lcd conector on the board of [/FONT][/FONT][/SIZE][SIZE=16px][FONT=Courier][FONT=Courier]<SIGNAL>PPVOUT_SW_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> [/FONT][/FONT][/SIZE]look like burn but paths to capacitors there are still good.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> question
threads.message:
The LCD is not recognized! Doing some stupid shit is NOT going to magically fix this.
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>DDC_CLK</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>DDC_DATA</SIGNAL> are involved in this. Seeing that you said there was corrosion on the LCD connector it is probably fucked.

If diode mode on all these 3 signals show something the it is probably the connector/cable

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>                        = .353



I will try to do less stupid things :P I will solder back <TRANSISTOR>Q9706</TRANSISTOR> nad remove the wire.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> question
threads.message: That seems ok, but you never know with <SIGNAL>3V_S0</SIGNAL>. If there is corrosion on the connector at any point I would replace it. Have you also tried another LCD assembly? Are you sure <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> is high?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> question
threads.message: One of the LVDS lines is missing or shorted together or GND. Again take an LCD cable and measure all LVDS lines to the other side. Also check if pins are shorted together. L9080 is also infamous for being damaged, measure lines after it on diode mode all LVDS line should be the same value.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> question
threads.message: all LVDS lines are .654 some .664 with cable connected I replace L9080 and problem still remain

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> question
threads.message:
You don't replace L9080 if it measures fine! Measure again with a separate cable and measure on LCD end.
Also that .654 MUST go down on all lines when you plug in an LCD!

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> question
threads.message: hello masters , since I have no cable I decide to run ASD just to see if something else is wrong and take care of that , and program find VPOR -- PBUS fail , how I can find witch one is it on the board?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> question
threads.message:
[QUOTE="pcfriends, post: 2156"]hello masters , since I have no cable I decide to run ASD just to see if something else is wrong and take care of that , and program find VPOR -- PBUS fail , how I can find witch one is it on the board?[/QUOTE]

Schematics, if you type Vp0R you will see it. Notice... that is not "O" is 0 (zero)
IF not try typing [FONT=Courier]PBUS Voltage Sense Enable & Filter
Then check in board view
Visual inspection on resistors, if they look like C&B, replace them[/FONT]

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> question
threads.message: Corrosion around <TRANSISTOR>Q5300</TRANSISTOR>, usually pin 4 is gone or the resistors next to it.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> question
threads.message: thank you , I will replace it as soon as I can and I will check the paths

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> question
threads.message: hello masters , I finally was able to fix this board , I solder a new lcd conector and now is working fine thank you!
